elements.content: Ab initio wavefunction and density functional theory calculations have been performed to investigate the second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of the bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato}-zinc(II) metal–organic framework (MOF). This has been carried out by adopting the supramolecular or cluster approach, which consists in analyzing the evolution of the first hyperpolarizability as a function of the number of units of the system. In a first step, the impact of the method of calculation has been assessed, evidencing that the exchange-correlation functional has a stronger impact on the first hyperpolarizability (β) values than the basis set. Still, the first hyperpolarizability values related to the hyper-Rayleigh scattering (HRS) (βHRS) are slightly more sensitive to the Zn basis set than to that of the other atoms, but the combination of the LANL2DZ basis for Zn with the 6-31G* basis set for the other atoms provides stable results with respect to adding supplementary valence, polarization, and diffuse functions as demonstrated by the variations of βHRS that remain smaller than 6%. Several structure/property relationships have then been deduced for the β of this MOF: (i) the lack of coordination of the ligands extremities enhances β because their donor/acceptor characters are not damped by the Zn2+ cations, (ii) the β of clusters expanding in one direction increases almost linearly with the cluster size, (iii) the deviations with respect to linearity are smaller than 25%, which differ from organic molecular crystals, and (iv) the octupolar component of the β response is of the same order of magnitude as its dipolar counterpart, and its relative importance generally increases with the cluster size.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), also known as coordination polymers (CPs) or coordination networks, have emerged as an interesting class of inorganic–organic hybrid materials, which can be fine-tuned at the molecular level. MOFs have many potential and practical applications in the fields of gas storage, separations, chemical and radiation sensing, catalysis, imaging, solid-state lighting, drug delivery, electronic devices, and nonlinear optics. Interest on MOFs is rapidly accelerating especially in the field of nonlinear optics. Rational synthetic approaches to create MOFs with noncentrosymmetric linkers for second-order nonlinear optics were recently reviewed by Lin et al., and many MOFs with large second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) responses have been reported.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), also known as coordination polymers (CPs) or coordination networks, have emerged as an interesting class of inorganic-organic hybrid materials, which can be fine-tuned at the molecular level. MOFs have many potential and practical applications in the fields of gas storage, separations, chemical and radiation sensing, catalysis, imaging, solid-state lighting, drug delivery, electronic devices, and nonlinear optics. Interest on MOFs is rapidly accelerating especially in the field of nonlinear optics. Rational synthetic approaches to create MOFs with noncentrosymmetric linkers for second-order nonlinear optics were recently reviewed by Lin et al., and many MOFs with large second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) responses have been reported.

elements.content: However, understanding the electronic structure of MOFs and its relationship to the local and extended crystalline environment is only in the very early stages and systematic theoretical investigations of the MOF NLO properties have not yet been performed. The roles of the linker orientation, of the interchromophore distance and of the interpenetration are largely unknown. As a consequence, there is an interest in understanding the origin of the second-order NLO responses, providing therefore opportunities to control and to enhance these. Note that there are complementary interests for carrying out theoretical investigations on the thermodynamics and kinetics of MOF synthesis as well as for interpreting their spectroscopic signatures. In this work, using quantum chemical methods, we study the NLO properties of bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato}-zinc(II), a MOF built from Zn2+ tetrahedral connecting points and p-pyridinecarboxylate linkers presenting large second-order NLO responses. Though there exists a broad range of theoretical methods to evaluate the second-order NLO responses of solids, the large size of the unit cell makes difficult the application of many of these. Therefore, we have chosen to adopt the supramolecular or cluster approach where an aggregate of molecules or unit cells is considered as a giant molecule. This allows investigating the cluster size effects on the NLO responses as well as the impact of the terminal groups, whereas long-range interactions are truncated. Within this scheme, calculations on aggregates containing up to 719 atoms, corresponding to 4 tetrahedral units, are performed in this work.

elements.content: The article is organized as follows. The theoretical methods are briefly described in . In , the results are presented and discussed, starting with a comparison of the results obtained with different exchange-correlation (XC) functionals and basis sets () as well as with an investigation of tetrahedral units with different terminal functions (). The article continues with the study of clusters extending in different directions () before conclusions are drawn in .

elements.content: The molecular structures were optimized in vacuo at the density functional theory (DFT) level of approximation using the B3P86 hybrid XC functional. The atomic basis set combines the 6-31G* basis set for the C, H, N, and O atoms with the LANL2DZ effective core potential and valence electron basis set for the Zn atoms (abbreviated as LANL2DZ/6-31G*). The time-dependent Hartree–Fock (TDHF) and time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) schemes were applied for obtaining dynamic (frequency-dependent) first hyperpolarizabilities (β) at an incident wavelength of 1064 nm (ℏω = 1.165 eV). A few DFT XC functionals were selected to calculate β: (i) the B3P86 functional since it is already used for optimizing the geometries, (ii) the M06-2X functional, which contains a larger (56%) amount of HF exchange, (iii) the long-range corrected (LC) XC functional, LC-BLYP with a range-separating parameter μ of 0.47, and (iv) the ωB97X functional characterized by short-range and long-range HF exchange. Although their advantages with respect to the TDHF method are not completely delimited, LC XC functionals have been shown to correct conventional DFT schemes for their shortsighted drawbacks. These β calculations were carried out using a panoply of basis sets starting from the LANL2DZ/6-31G* ( and Table ). For extending one-dimensional clusters, the experimental single-crystal geometries were adopted without optimization. The dynamic β of these extended clusters were calculated using the TDHF, TDDFT/B3P86, and TDDFT/LC-BLYP approaches in combination with the LANL2DZ/6-31G* basis set.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical and Computational Aspects

The molecular structures were optimized in vacuo at the density functional theory (DFT) level of approximation using the B3P86 hybrid XC functional. The atomic basis set combines the 6-31G* basis set for the C, H, N, and O atoms with the LANL2DZ effective core potential and valence electron basis set for the Zn atoms (abbreviated as LANL2DZ/6-31G*). The time-dependent Hartree-Fock (TDHF) and time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) schemes were applied for obtaining dynamic (frequency-dependent) first hyperpolarizabilities (β) at an incident wavelength of 1064 nm (ℏω = 1.165 eV). A few DFT XC functionals were selected to calculate β: (i) the B3P86 functional since it is already used for optimizing the geometries, (ii) the M06-2X functional, which contains a larger (56%) amount of HF exchange, (iii) the long-range corrected (LC) XC functional, LC-BLYP with a range-separating parameter μ of 0.47, and (iv) the ωB97X functional characterized by short-range and long-range HF exchange. Although their advantages with respect to the TDHF method are not completely delimited, LC XC functionals have been shown to correct conventional DFT schemes for their shortsighted drawbacks. These β calculations were carried out using a panoply of basis sets starting from the LANL2DZ/6-31G* ( and Table ). For extending one-dimensional clusters, the experimental single-crystal geometries were adopted without optimization. The dynamic β of these extended clusters were calculated using the TDHF, TDDFT/B3P86, and TDDFT/LC-BLYP approaches in combination with the LANL2DZ/6-31G* basis set.

elements.content: In this study, we focused on the second-harmonic generation (SHG) response for which the β(−2ω;ω,ω) tensor contains 18 independent elements. In particular, the quantities under study are related to the hyper-Rayleigh scattering (HRS) experiments with nonpolarized incident laser light and observation of plane-polarized scattered light made perpendicular to the propagation plane. Assuming an incident light propagating along the X direction and a scattered light at 90° along the Y direction and vertically polarized along the Z axis, βHRS reads β HRS ( − 2 ω ; ω , ω ) = { ⟨ β Z Z Z 2 ⟩ + ⟨ β Z X X 2 ⟩ } the depolarization ratio, DR, which reveals the shape of the NLO-phore, is given by D R = I V V 2 ω I H V 2 ω = ⟨ β Z Z Z 2 ⟩ ⟨ β Z X X 2 ⟩ where ⟨β ZZZ 2⟩ and ⟨β ZXX 2⟩ are orientational averages of all the β tensor components in the molecular frame, which are proportional to the scattered signal for vertically and horizontally plane-polarized incident signals, respectively. We have also invoked the irreducible spherical representations of the β tensor to describe the symmetric rank-3 β tensor in terms of its dipolar (J = 1) and octupolar (J = 3) tensorial βJ components, as recently employed to describe ionic liquids and reference molecules: ⟨ β Z Z Z 2 ⟩ = 1 5 | β J = 1 | 2 + 2 35 | β J = 3 | 2 ⟨ β Z X X 2 ⟩ = 1 45 | β J = 1 | 2 + 4 105 | β J = 3 | 2 so that one can rewrite βHRS in the following way: β HRS = 2 9 | β J = 1 | 2 + 2 21 | β J = 3 | 2 and define the nonlinear anisotropy parameter ρ, which describes the amount of octupolar character with respect to the dipolar one: ρ = | β J = 3 | | β J = 1 | The quantities in eqs – were calculated without assuming Kleinman’s conditions. The β values are given within the B convention. All calculations were performed using Gaussian09.

elements.content: Each unit is built around a central Zn2+ cation coordinated by 4 Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligands but the coordination pattern is asymmetric in the sense that each ZnII center is coordinated twice by the N of a pyridine and twice by a carboxylate function. Our reference tetrahedral unit (model a, Figure ) is composed of these tetra-coordinated ZnII center and each bidentate ligand is terminated by another tetracoordinated ZnII center. The three other ligands of the terminal ZnII centers are reduced to pyridine and formate moieties (2 + 1 or 1 + 2 to satisfy the asymmetric coordination pattern). The chemical formula for this species is Zn5C92H76N10O20. As an alternative, we considered the tetrahedral unit without the capping Zn groups (ZnC56H40N4O8 2–, model b, Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Each unit is built around a central Zn2+ cation coordinated by 4 Py-CHCH-Ph-COO- ligands but the coordination pattern is asymmetric in the sense that each ZnII center is coordinated twice by the N of a pyridine and twice by a carboxylate function. Our reference tetrahedral unit (model a, Figure ) is composed of these tetra-coordinated ZnII center and each bidentate ligand is terminated by another tetracoordinated ZnII center. The three other ligands of the terminal ZnII centers are reduced to pyridine and formate moieties (2 + 1 or 1 + 2 to satisfy the asymmetric coordination pattern). The chemical formula for this species is Zn5C92H76N10O20. As an alternative, we considered the tetrahedral unit without the capping Zn groups (ZnC56H40N4O8 2-, model b, Figure ).

elements.content: Clusters expanding in different directions as well as the crystal unit cell were then considered by building clusters from the crystal structure (without optimization) and terminating each bidentate ligand by another tetracoordinated ZnII center saturated with pyridine and formate moieties. Like in previous studies, these one-dimensional clusters aim at assessing the variations of the first hyperpolarizability as a function of the size of the clusters and therefore to assess the NLO response of the three-dimensional crystalline solid.

Like in previous studies, these one-dimensional clusters aim at assessing the variations of the first hyperpolarizability as a function of the size of the clusters and therefore to assess the NLO response of the three-dimensional crystalline solid.

elements.content: The a and b structures were used to compare the results obtained at different levels of approximation, using different XC functionals and basis sets. Some calculations were also carried out on the protonated analogue of structure b (ZnC56H42N4O8, bH). The XC functional (Table ) has a much stronger impact on the β (βHRS, |β J=1|, and |β J=3|) quantities than the basis set (Table ). As found for many push–pull π-conjugated systems, as well as for the Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand, pure DFT exchange is associated with huge increases of the first hyperpolarizabilities. Indeed, besides bH having a much smaller response, the βB3P86/βTDHF ratio attains a value of about 3, whereas the LC-BLYP β values are only 50% larger than the TDHF ones, evidencing the overestimation of the B3P86 values owing to the too small response part of the exchange potential that does not sufficiently counteract the external electric field. Indeed, LC-BLYP contains 100% of HF exchange in the long-range limit, whereas B3P86 is characterized by a fixed 20% amount of HF exchange. M06-2X containing 56% of HF exchange leads to β results intermediately between those of LC-BLYP and B3P86, while ωB97X containing 100% of long-range HF exchange leads to β results between those of M06-2X and LC-BLYP, again besides bH of which the response is not driven by a push–pull π-conjugated character.
elements.clean_text:
XC Functional and Basis Set Effects

The a and b structures were used to compare the results obtained at different levels of approximation, using different XC functionals and basis sets. Some calculations were also carried out on the protonated analogue of structure b (ZnC56H42N4O8, bH). The XC functional (Table ) has a much stronger impact on the β (βHRS, |β J=1|, and |β J=3|) quantities than the basis set (Table ). As found for many push-pull π-conjugated systems, as well as for the Py-CHCH-Ph-COO- ligand, pure DFT exchange is associated with huge increases of the first hyperpolarizabilities. Indeed, besides bH having a much smaller response, the βB3P86/βTDHF ratio attains a value of about 3, whereas the LC-BLYP β values are only 50% larger than the TDHF ones, evidencing the overestimation of the B3P86 values owing to the too small response part of the exchange potential that does not sufficiently counteract the external electric field. Indeed, LC-BLYP contains 100% of HF exchange in the long-range limit, whereas B3P86 is characterized by a fixed 20% amount of HF exchange. M06-2X containing 56% of HF exchange leads to β results intermediately between those of LC-BLYP and B3P86, while ωB97X containing 100% of long-range HF exchange leads to β results between those of M06-2X and LC-BLYP, again besides bH of which the response is not driven by a push-pull π-conjugated character.

The impact of the XC functional on the ratio between the octupolar and dipolar contributions to β is smaller than on its individual quantities, at least for the a and b units and for the ligand. In the case of bH, the β values are much smaller, which might explain why changing the XC functional provokes a modification of the dipolar/octupolar character. Anyway, among this set of 5 functionals, the most different ρ value is obtained with the B3P86 XC functional. Owing to this consistency with previous results on other systems, the LC-BLYP XC functional was selected to study the impact of the basis set.

elements.content: Two aspects of the basis sets were assessed: (i) the description of the Zn atoms and (ii) the description of the other atoms. For the Zn atoms, different effective core potentials and valence atomic orbital basis sets (LANL2MB, LANL2DZ, and SDDALL) were employed in comparison with full electron basis sets. For other atoms, typical all-electron atomic basis sets for calculating hyperpolarizabilities of large systems were used: 6-31G*, 6-31+G*, 6-311G*, 6-311G**, cc-pVDZ, and cc-PVTZ. As can be seen (Table ), the impact of basis set on the β (βHRS, |β J=1|, and |β J=3|) quantities is generally small and similar to the basis set effects on the first hyperpolarizabilities of extended π-conjugated systems, where atoms on neighboring sites help describing the hyperpolarizations on a given site (molecular fragment) and where diffuse functions have a negligible impact.

For other atoms, typical all-electron atomic basis sets for calculating hyperpolarizabilities of large systems were used: 6-31G*, 6-31+G*, 6-311G*, 6-311G**, cc-pVDZ, and cc-PVTZ. As can be seen (Table ), the impact of basis set on the β (βHRS, |β J=1|, and |β J=3|) quantities is generally small and similar to the basis set effects on the first hyperpolarizabilities of extended π-conjugated systems, where atoms on neighboring sites help describing the hyperpolarizations on a given site (molecular fragment) and where diffuse functions have a negligible impact.

elements.content: For model a, when LANL2MB is employed on Zn, changing the basis set for the other atoms from the split-valence double-ζ polarized basis set (6-31G*) to the split-valence triple-ζ polarized basis set (6-311G*) increases the βHRS value by only 0.1%, while adding a second set of polarization functions onto 6-311G* further increases the βHRS value by only 0.8%. Then, there is only 0.9% difference between the βHRS response calculated with the correlation-consistent polarized double-ζ basis set (cc-pVDZ) and the different split-valence polarized basis sets. Changing the correlation-consistent polarized double-ζ basis set (cc-pVDZ) to the correlation-consistent polarized triple-ζ basis set (cc-pVTZ), which corresponds to more than doubling the number of basis functions, also increases the βHRS value by 0.7%. Thus, the largest difference occurs between the 6-31G* and cc-pVTZ βHRS responses and it is only 1.6%. When the LANL2DZ and SDDAll basis sets are employed for Zn, the largest variations on βHRS among the different all-electron atomic basis sets (to describe the other atoms) are as small as 2.0% and 1.2%, respectively. In the case where Zn is described by the LANL2DZ basis set, the effect of adding diffuse functions on the other atoms, going from 6-31G* to 6-31+G* has been confirmed to be negligible (2%). Note that calculations with basis sets including diffuse functions are particularly difficult to achieve, owing to the slow convergence of the SCF procedure. Moreover, when typical all-electron basis sets are employed for both Zn and the other atoms, the largest difference among the βHRS values calculated with different basis sets remains small, though it increases to 5.4%. Again, the difference between 6-31G* and cc-pVTZ is less than 4%.

elements.content: Looking at the basis set effects by considering a fixed all-electron basis set for all atoms except Zn but different basis sets on the latter atoms (all-electron versus effective core potential), one concludes that the βHRS values are slightly more sensitive to the description of the Zn atoms than these of the other ones. For instance, changing the basis set on the Zn atom from LANL2MB to LANL2DZ decreases the calculated βHRS value by 2.2%, 1.7%, 1.7%, and 2.0% when the 6-31G*, 6-311G*, 6-311G**, and cc-pVDZ basis set are employed on the other atoms, respectively. Similar variations are observed when going from LANL2DZ to the all-electron basis set on Zn atoms. Summarizing the impact of basis set on both the Zn and other atoms, the smallest βHRS amounts to 1569 au (LANL2DZ/6-31G*) and the largest to 1659 au (cc-pVTZ/cc-pVTZ), resulting in a variation as small as 5.7%.

For instance, changing the basis set on the Zn atom from LANL2MB to LANL2DZ decreases the calculated βHRS value by 2.2%, 1.7%, 1.7%, and 2.0% when the 6-31G*, 6-311G*, 6-311G**, and cc-pVDZ basis set are employed on the other atoms, respectively. Similar variations are observed when going from LANL2DZ to the all-electron basis set on Zn atoms. Summarizing the impact of basis set on both the Zn and other atoms, the smallest βHRS amounts to 1569 au (LANL2DZ/6-31G*) and the largest to 1659 au (cc-pVTZ/cc-pVTZ), resulting in a variation as small as 5.7%.

elements.content: This analysis was extended by considering structure b, though only the LANL2DZ basis set was used for Zn. Using the LANL2DZ/6-31G* basis set, βHRS is about 3.5% smaller than with the LANL2DZ/6-311G** basis set, or 2.8% smaller than with the LANL2DZ/cc-pVDZ one. Moreover, basis set effects on |β J=1| and |β J=3| for both the a and b model compounds are similar to those described for βHRS. As a consequence, the basis set effects on ρ are negligible.

Moreover, basis set effects on |β J=1| and |β J=3| for both the a and b model compounds are similar to those described for βHRS. As a consequence, the basis set effects on ρ are negligible.

elements.content: In summary, the influence of the basis set on β-related quantities is generally very small. Considering the interplay between accuracy and computational requirements, the LANL2DZ/6-31G* basis set was selected for the rest of the study on the various MOF architectures.

elements.content: As shown in Table , the responses of the tetrahedral units vary as a function of the nature of the terminal groups. In order to analyze β of these tetrahedrons as resulting from the combination of the responses of its constitutive units, the β response of the Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand is considered. At λ = 1064 nm, βHRS(DR) of Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– amounts to 3637 au (4.84), 1259 au (4.93), and 1746 au (5.02) according to B3P86, TDHF, and LC-BLYP calculations, respectively. When four Py-CHCH–Ph–COO– ligands coordinate the central Zn2+ cation to form a tetrahedral unit (model b), βHRS attains 9210, 3213, and 4719 au according to the B3P86, TDHF, and LC-BLYP approximations, respectively, which correspond to 2.5–2.7 times the βHRS of a single Py-CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand. In addition, owing to the tetrahedral structure of b, all methods predict a decrease of the depolarization ratios, by about one unit in comparison with the DR ≈ 5 values of the ligand, associated with its one-dimensional character.
elements.clean_text:
β Response of the Tetrahedral Units

As shown in Table , the responses of the tetrahedral units vary as a function of the nature of the terminal groups. In order to analyze β of these tetrahedrons as resulting from the combination of the responses of its constitutive units, the β response of the Py-CHCH-Ph-COO- ligand is considered. At λ = 1064 nm, βHRS(DR) of Py-CHCH-Ph-COO- amounts to 3637 au (4.84), 1259 au (4.93), and 1746 au (5.02) according to B3P86, TDHF, and LC-BLYP calculations, respectively. When four Py-CHCH-Ph-COO- ligands coordinate the central Zn2+ cation to form a tetrahedral unit (model b), βHRS attains 9210, 3213, and 4719 au according to the B3P86, TDHF, and LC-BLYP approximations, respectively, which correspond to 2.5-2.7 times the βHRS of a single Py-CHCH-Ph-COO- ligand. In addition, owing to the tetrahedral structure of b, all methods predict a decrease of the depolarization ratios, by about one unit in comparison with the DR ~ 5 values of the ligand, associated with its one-dimensional character.

elements.content: Terminating each bidentate ligand of model b by another tetra-coordinated ZnII center saturated with pyridine and formate moieties to get the neutral model a significantly decreases βHRS but restores more or less the DR of the ligand. In fact, any level of approximation predicts that βHRS(b)/βHRS(a) ≈ 3. We argue that this exaltation of βHRS in b with respect to a comes from the absence of coordination of the terminal ligands and to the global −2 charge of b, whereas a is neutral. The calculations on the bH system substantiate this analysis since its βHRS is as small as 494, 232, and 433 au according to B3P86, TDHF, and LC-BLYP calculations, respectively, i.e., less than 1/10 of those of b. Moreover, the comparison between a and bH demonstrates the important electron-withdrawing role of the Zn2+ cations. The evolution of the amplitude of the nonlinear anisotropy parameter follows inversely that of the depolarization ratios: at any level of approximation, ρ is slightly smaller than one for model a, demonstrating the predominance of the dipolar contribution to β, whereas it is slightly larger than one for model b, corresponding to a slight predominance of the octupolar contribution. Note that the DR of model a is equal to the typical value of one-dimensional NLO-phores (like the ligand), though model a is not one-dimensional. In fact, a looks in first approximation like a typical Λ-shape molecule with two (three for SHG) dominant independent tensor components: using the LC-BLYP XC functional, β yyy = 1338 au and β yxx (≈ β xyx = β xxy ) = 1960 au. Nevertheless, owing to the 3D tetrahedral nature of this compound, there are other nonnegligible tensor components: β yzz (≈ β zyz = β zzy ) = 511 au and the 6 β xyz -like components of 224 au (Table ). In contrast, the DR of b drops to 4.0. The reasons are (i) the repulsion between the negative charges on the two top uncoordinated −COO– groups, which leads to a larger angle between the two Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligands in b than in a, (ii) the exaltation of the major tensor components including β xyz , and (iii) subsequent decrease of the relative amplitude of β yyy with respect to β yxx and β yzz . The DR of bH is slightly smaller than b, confirming the significant influence of the negative charge in model b on β. Comparing the βHRS and DR of a with those of the Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand shows that, though their DR values are almost the same, the βHRS of model a is in fact even smaller than that of a single Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand. These results indicate that the tetracoordinated ZnII centers saturated with pyridine and formate moieties at the ligand terminations have a significant influence on the donor/acceptor (D/A) character of the different moieties and therefore on the β response of the tetrahedral units.

No β|| since model b is charged.

To clarify the D/A character in the different units, a natural population analysis (NPA) was performed for models a and b as well as for the Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand (Table ). In the ligand, most of the negative charge (−0.75 e, with e the magnitude of the electron charge) is distributed on the −COO– segment with residual values of −0.14 e and −0.14 e on the −Py and −Ph– segments, indicating the strongest electron donating potential of the carboxylate segment. When the central Zn2+ cation in model b is coordinated by the carboxylate of the ligand, Zn2+ receives −0.25 e from each ligand, which are distributed among the −Py, −CHCH–, −Ph–, and −COO– segments according to 0.06, 0.03, 0.10, and 0.06 e, respectively. However, the coordination of Zn2+ by the −Py site only brings −0.11 e per ligand, with most of the charge coming from the −Py segment. These results indicate that the Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand operates as a stronger donor when coordinating the Zn2+ cation with the carboxylate moiety than with the −Py site, though most of the transferred electrons come from the −Py or −Ph– segments.

Py for TL and TR and HCOO– for BL and BR.

Since both the −COO– and −Py sites of the ligand can donate electron when coordinated with Zn2+, the situation in model a is more complicated. The charge of the Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand in model a amounts to −0.65 e. Thus, this result can be explained within an additive model: each ligand donates about −0.09 e to the Zn2+ to which its −Py moiety is attached, whereas it gives −0.26 e to the Zn2+ coordinated by the carboxylate moiety. In addition, the Py and HCOO– segments saturating the capping Zn2+ also donate about −0.09 and −0.28 e, respectively, to their capping atoms. Considering that the −0.28 e given by the HCOO– moiety is very close to the −0.26 e coming from the Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand, one can conclude that all the Zn2+ cations have the same chemical and charge environment, making model a an ideal unit cell to simulate the MOF crystal. In contrast, the two pairs of ligands are not equal in model b, making model b a less realistic model. Since the structure and charge of the ligands in b have a significant influence on β, we consider that the β results of model a are more reliable than those of model b to describe the NLO responses of the MOF structures. As a consequence, for the expanded clusters, the terminal bidentate ligands are all linked to tetracoordinated ZnII center saturated with pyridine and formate moieties.

The charge of the Py-CHCH-Ph-COO- ligand in model a amounts to -0.65 e. Thus, this result can be explained within an additive model: each ligand donates about -0.09 e to the Zn2+ to which its -Py moiety is attached, whereas it gives -0.26 e to the Zn2+ coordinated by the carboxylate moiety. In addition, the Py and HCOO- segments saturating the capping Zn2+ also donate about -0.09 and -0.28 e, respectively, to their capping atoms. Considering that the -0.28 e given by the HCOO- moiety is very close to the -0.26 e coming from the Py-CHCH-Ph-COO- ligand, one can conclude that all the Zn2+ cations have the same chemical and charge environment, making model a an ideal unit cell to simulate the MOF crystal. In contrast, the two pairs of ligands are not equal in model b, making model b a less realistic model. Since the structure and charge of the ligands in b have a significant influence on β, we consider that the β results of model a are more reliable than those of model b to describe the NLO responses of the MOF structures. As a consequence, for the expanded clusters, the terminal bidentate ligands are all linked to tetracoordinated ZnII center saturated with pyridine and formate moieties.

elements.content: Four types of expanded clusters were then built from the X-ray diffraction geometrical structures. They differ by the nature of the growth scheme (Figure ). A BL-TR-Zn-BL-TR-Zn growing pattern provides a linear structure (named 2L, 3L, and 4L for 2, 3, and 4 unit cells, respectively), whereas the TL-TR-Zn-TL-TR-Zn and BL-TR-Zn-TL-BR-Zn-BL-TR-Zn give W-type and Z-type structures (named 2W, 3W, and 4W or 2Z, 3Z, and 4Z for 2, 3, and 4 unit cells), respectively. By construction, the 2Z and 2W structures are identical. Another W-like structure is obtained from growing the BL-TL-Zn-BL-TL-Zn pattern. Since this is along the y direction, they are named as 2yW, 3yW, and 4yW for 2, 3, and 4 unit cells. In addition, on the basis of the two independent ZnII centers in the asymmetric crystal unit, a cluster with three nonoptimized unit cells (named CryUnit) is built. Since the clusters are built according to the single-crystal structure without optimization, we also considered the nonoptimized tetrahedral unit (model a′) for comparison.
elements.clean_text:
β Response of Expanded Clusters

Four types of expanded clusters were then built from the X-ray diffraction geometrical structures. They differ by the nature of the growth scheme (Figure ). A BL-TR-Zn-BL-TR-Zn growing pattern provides a linear structure (named 2L, 3L, and 4L for 2, 3, and 4 unit cells, respectively), whereas the TL-TR-Zn-TL-TR-Zn and BL-TR-Zn-TL-BR-Zn-BL-TR-Zn give W-type and Z-type structures (named 2W, 3W, and 4W or 2Z, 3Z, and 4Z for 2, 3, and 4 unit cells), respectively. By construction, the 2Z and 2W structures are identical. Another W-like structure is obtained from growing the BL-TL-Zn-BL-TL-Zn pattern. Since this is along the y direction, they are named as 2yW, 3yW, and 4yW for 2, 3, and 4 unit cells. In addition, on the basis of the two independent ZnII centers in the asymmetric crystal unit, a cluster with three nonoptimized unit cells (named CryUnit) is built. Since the clusters are built according to the single-crystal structure without optimization, we also considered the nonoptimized tetrahedral unit (model a') for comparison.

elements.content: In comparison to the optimized structure (a), the use of the X-ray diffraction geometrical structures (a′) leads to an increase of βHRS by 26%, 25%, and 39% at the TDHF, TDDFT/B3P86, and TDDFT/LC-BLYP levels of approximation, respectively (Table ). Part of this effect comes from the change of cluster shape (upon geometry optimization, the angles between the ligand arms can vary by as much as 20°). Indeed, when considering the structure where the five Zn2+ cations are fixed but the other geometrical parameters are optimized (a-fixZn) βHRS increases by only 14%, 11%, and 11% with respect to the results on the fully optimized structures using the TDHF, TDDFT/B3P86, and TDDFT/LC-BLYP schemes, respectively. These results confirm that the β response is sensitive to the molecular structure, also in MOF, like in organic and organometallic compounds, though the effects of bond length alternation in the latter are generally much larger. However, such systematic increase of βHRS resulting from the lack of geometry optimization is assumed to be similar for the different clusters, or in other words, these geometrical effects are expected to play a minor role on the trends between the β of the different expanded clusters. As a consequence, calculations on the expanded clusters are based on structures taken from the single-crystal structure without geometry optimization, which reduces the substantial computational efforts that would have been needed to optimize the geometry of a cluster as large as 4 L containing 719 atoms.

At all levels of approximation, βHRS increases monotonically from a′ to 4L, 4W, 4Z, and 4yW. Following our strategy to saturate the outer ligand by capped Zn2+ cations, none of the clusters correspond exactly to an integer number of unit cells, but each Zn2+ cation has the same chemical environment. For example, the formula of 3L is Zn13C252H204N26O52, which differs from three times the formula of a′ (3Zn5C92H76N10O20 = Zn15C276H228N30O60). Therefore, in order to assess the intrinsic unit contribution to the first hyperpolarizability, the cluster β values have either been divided by the number of units (N units) or by the number of zinc atoms (N Zn). This defines two packing ratios: R units = β HRS , cluster / ( N units β HRS , a ′ ) R Zn = β HRS , cluster / ( N Zn β HRS , a ′ / 5 )

elements.content: According to the TDHF approximation, the βHRS,cluster increases from 1327 au for a′ to 5573 au for 4L, leading to slightly increasing R units from 1.00 for a′ to 1.01, 1.04, and 1.05 for 2L, 3L, and 4L, respectively. However, when referring to the number of zinc atoms, the ratio R Zn increases to 1.13, 1.19, and 1.24 for 2L, 3L, and 4L, respectively (Figure ). TDDFT/B3P86 calculations show the same trend as the TDHF method but with slightly larger ratios. Then, according to LC-BLYP calculations, the R units ratios are smaller than one: 0.85, 0.88, and 0.89 for 2L, 3L, and 4L, while the R Zn values are also slightly larger: 0.95, 1.01, and 1.05 for 2L, 3L, and 4L, respectively. The yW-type clusters show the same trends as L-type clusters but with slightly smaller ratios.

However, when referring to the number of zinc atoms, the ratio R Zn increases to 1.13, 1.19, and 1.24 for 2L, 3L, and 4L, respectively (Figure ). elements.clean_text: 3  Packing ratios R units (left) and R Zn (right) determined at the TDHF (squares), LC-BLYP (circles), and B3P86 (triangles) levels of approximation for linear (black), W-type (red), Z-type (blue), and yW-type (green) clusters.

elements.content: For the W-type clusters, the packing effects on β go in the opposite direction. The R units calculated with all three levels of approximation are smaller than one and decrease with the number of units. From 2W to 4W, R units goes from 0.92 to 0.90 at the TDHF level, from 0.77 to 0.75 with the LC-BLYP functional, and from 0.88 to 0.85 using B3P86. Then, going from 2W to 4W, R Zn increases slightly, from 1.02 to 1.06 (TDHF), from 0.86 to 0.89 (LC-BLYP), and from 0.98 to 1.00 (B3P86). For a given size, R units(TDHF) > R units(B3P86) > R units(LC-BLYP), whereas βHRS(B3P86) > βHRS(LC-BLYP) > βHRS(TDHF). For the Z-type clusters, all levels of approximation provide the same trends for the size dependence of R units and R Zn as for the corresponding W-type clusters, while the TDHF and LC-BLYP βHRS values are slightly smaller but the B3P86 ones slightly larger.
elements.clean_text: For the W-type clusters, the packing effects on β go in the opposite direction. The R units calculated with all three levels of approximation are smaller than one and decrease with the number of units. From 2W to 4W, R units goes from 0.92 to 0.90 at the TDHF level, from 0.77 to 0.75 with the LC-BLYP functional, and from 0.88 to 0.85 using B3P86. Then, going from 2W to 4W, R Zn increases slightly, from 1.02 to 1.06 (TDHF), from 0.86 to 0.89 (LC-BLYP), and from 0.98 to 1.00 (B3P86). For a given size, R units(TDHF) > R units(B3P86) > R units(LC-BLYP), whereas βHRS(B3P86) > βHRS(LC-BLYP) > βHRS(TDHF). For the Z-type clusters, all levels of approximation provide the same trends for the size dependence of R units and R Zn as for the corresponding W-type clusters, while the TDHF and LC-BLYP βHRS values are slightly smaller but the B3P86 ones slightly larger.

elements.content: For CryUnit, βHRS amounts to 2745, 3719, and 4561 au at the TDHF, TDDFT/B3P86, and TDDFT/LC-BLYP levels, respectively, which attains only 2.07, 1.70, and 1.86 times βHRS of a′, though there are three a′ in the CryUnit cluster. The corresponding R units = R Zn quantities are therefore smaller (0.69, 0.57, and 0.62) in comparison with those of the Zn-coordinated units of the L-, W-, yW-, and Z-type clusters. This reduction of the packing ratios is accompanied by an increase of the octupolar character of the second-order NLO response.

elements.content: Summarizing the above results, both the TDHF and B3P86 approaches predict that (i) R units and R Zn increase as a function of the size for both the L- and yW-type clusters, (ii) R units decreases for W- and Z-type clusters, and (iii) R Zn increases for the W- and Z-type clusters. On the contrary, the LC-BLYP functional predicts that the R units and R Zn of L- and yW-type clusters first decrease and then increase, whereas for the W- and Z-type clusters, after a decrease, the packing ratios decrease/increase slightly. In other words, the LC-BLYP results are different from those with TDHF and B3P86, whereas the L- and yW-type clusters display different trends with cluster size in comparison to the W- and Z-type clusters. Despite this, (i) all the packing ratios, for all linear cluster types and with all methods, are close to one and tend to saturate rapidly with the cluster size, which demonstrates that the cluster approach is efficient to assess the NLO response of the crystal and (ii) the ratios for L- and yW-type clusters are larger than for W- and Z-type clusters. For all cluster types, the ratios calculated with LC-BLYP functional are the smallest among the three levels of approximation.

For all cluster types, the ratios calculated with LC-BLYP functional are the smallest among the three levels of approximation.

elements.content: The trends between the ratios of the different types of clusters can be qualitatively explained by resorting to the angle between the dipole moment, or the charge transfer direction, and the packing direction. In L-type clusters, half of the ligands are oriented almost parallel to the growing direction (the a angle is as large as 129.5°), leading to a dipole moment making a b angle of 50.5° with the growing direction. Such a quasi parallel alignment of the D/A moieties is known to lead to an enhancement of the first hyperpolarizability per unit, contrary to parallel alignments that lead to the opposite effect. These effects are based on simple electrostatic rules and can explain the packing effects on β of molecular crystals. In the case of MOFs, there is a second effect because the units are linked through ZnII centers and therefore a (quasi) parallel alignment of the ligands also enables charge transfer over longer distances. The yW-type clusters are also characterized by a β enhancement since half of the ligands are oriented in the growing direction, but since the a angle is smaller (91.1°), the packing ratios are smaller than for the L-type clusters.

These effects are based on simple electrostatic rules and can explain the packing effects on β of molecular crystals. In the case of MOFs, there is a second effect because the units are linked through ZnII centers and therefore a (quasi) parallel alignment of the ligands also enables charge transfer over longer distances. The yW-type clusters are also characterized by a β enhancement since half of the ligands are oriented in the growing direction, but since the a angle is smaller (91.1°), the packing ratios are smaller than for the L-type clusters.

elements.content: The situation gets different for the W- and Z-type clusters because the organization of the ligands leads to a resulting dipole moment almost perpendicular to the cluster expansion direction (b = 89.6° and 90.4–92.6° for W- and Z-type clusters). Thus, in average, the charge transfer direction is also perpendicular to the growing direction, preventing an efficient charge transfer in this direction. This translates into small β xxx values (LC-BLYP): −73 au and 397 au for 3W and 3Z with respect to 10 702 au and −4298 au for 3L and 3yW, respectively. In fact, the damping of β is even stronger in 3Z- than in 3W-type clusters since the central zinc atoms of the different units are not aligned. Not surprisingly, the packing ratios in CryUnit are much smaller in comparison with those of the Zn-coordinated units of the L-, yW-, W-, and Z-type linear clusters because the units in CryUnit are independent of each other, preventing the charge transfer between the units.

elements.content: The ρ values also evolve as a function of the cluster size and of the growing direction, though both the dipolar and octupolar contributions are always of similar amplitude. At the TDHF level, the ρ values are smaller than one (0.70–0.95), the CryUnit displays more octupolar character than the reference cluster a′, whereas the yW-type clusters are more dipolar. At the LC-BLYP level, the linear clusters have more octupolar character than a′, and the ρ values are always very close to one, except for the yW-type clusters for which they are close to 0.9. Though the ρ values are larger, the B3P86 calculations also account for an increase of octupolar character upon cluster growth, except again for the yW-type clusters.

elements.content: In this first theoretical investigation on the second-order NLO properties of MOF, the first hyperpolarizability of the bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato}-zinc(II) MOF has been calculated with ab initio wave function and density functional theory methods combined with the cluster approach, which consists in probing the evolution of the first hyperpolarizability as a function of the cluster size and shape.
elements.clean_text:
Further Discussions, Conclusions, and Outlook

In this first theoretical investigation on the second-order NLO properties of MOF, the first hyperpolarizability of the bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato}-zinc(II) MOF has been calculated with ab initio wave function and density functional theory methods combined with the cluster approach, which consists in probing the evolution of the first hyperpolarizability as a function of the cluster size and shape.

elements.content: In a first step, the impact of the method of calculation has been assessed, evidencing that the XC functional has a much stronger impact on the β values (βHRS, |β J=1|, and |β J=3|) than the basis set. Still, the βHRS values are slightly more sensitive to the Zn basis set than to that of the other atoms, but the combination of the LANL2DZ basis for Zn with the 6-31G* basis set for the other atoms provides stable results with respect to adding additional valence, polarization, and diffuse functions as demonstrated by variations of βHRS that remain smaller than 6%.

Still, the βHRS values are slightly more sensitive to the Zn basis set than to that of the other atoms, but the combination of the LANL2DZ basis for Zn with the 6-31G* basis set for the other atoms provides stable results with respect to adding additional valence, polarization, and diffuse functions as demonstrated by variations of βHRS that remain smaller than 6%.

elements.content: Several structure/property relationships have been deduced for the β of this MOF: (i) the lack of coordination of the ligand extremities enhances β because their D/A character is not damped by the Zn2+ cations, (ii) the first hyperpolarizability of clusters extending in one direction increases almost linearly with the cluster size, (iii) the deviations with respect to linearity are smaller than 25%, which differs from organic molecular crystals, (iv) the octupolar component of the β response is of the same order of magnitude as its dipolar counterpart and its relative importance generally increases with the cluster size, and (v) the amplitude of the packing ratios fulfills generally the R(L) > R(yW) > R(W) > R(Z) > R(CryUnit) ordering and can be explained on the basis of simple electrostatics.

elements.content: The understanding of the structure/NLO property relationships in MOF and the design of MOF with dedicated NLO responses are, however, still in its infancy, and many aspects remain to be investigated. For instance, the nature of the cation is expected to modify the NLO response. As a preliminary step toward such investigation, we have carried out a calculation of the first hyperpolarizability of the tetrahedral unit of the bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato}-cadmium(II) MOF, the analogue of the title compound where the Zn atoms are replaced by Cd atoms. This has been performed with the LC-BLYP XC functional and the LANL2DZ/6-31G* basis set on the X-ray diffraction geometry. The βHRS response attains 2159 au with a DR of 4.44, both of which are smaller than that in bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato}-zinc(II) MOF (2185 au and 5.11, respectively). The ratio of the βHRS responses, βHRS(Cd)/βHRS(Zn) = 0.99 is similar to the ratios between the SHG responses of the corresponding MOF structures, 345/400 = 0.86, where the SHG activity is given as multiples of the α-quartz value. After geometry optimization, βHRS of the Cd(II) MOF reduces to 1449 au, and the corresponding βHRS(Cd)/βHRS(Zn) ratio to 0.92, in better agreement with the experimental value on the crystal structures.

elements.content: Other structural modifications can be analyzed by changing the nature of the molecular moieties linking the cations since they will impact the angles between the packing directions, the dipole moments, and the charge transfer directions, and, therefore, the first hyperpolarizabilities. Another extension would consist in monitoring the variations in the first hyperpolarizabilities when molecules fill the MOF cages as well as in describing the switching of the NLO responses of MOF. From the computational and theoretical points of view, it would be interesting to carry out NLO property calculations on the periodic three-dimensional MOF structure, adopting band structure approaches since they will allow a direct prediction of the NLO responses of the crystal without considering different one-dimensional clusters.

From the computational and theoretical points of view, it would be interesting to carry out NLO property calculations on the periodic three-dimensional MOF structure, adopting band structure approaches since they will allow a direct prediction of the NLO responses of the crystal without considering different one-dimensional clusters.

cln_elements.content:
As shown in Table , the responses of the tetrahedral units vary as a function of the nature of the terminal groups. In order to analyze β of these tetrahedrons as resulting from the combination of the responses of its constitutive units, the β response of the Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand is considered. At λ = 1064 nm, βHRS(DR) of Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– amounts to 3637 au (4.84), 1259 au (4.93), and 1746 au (5.02) according to B3P86, TDHF, and LC-BLYP calculations, respectively. When four Py-CHCH–Ph–COO– ligands coordinate the central Zn2+ cation to form a tetrahedral unit (model b), βHRS attains 9210, 3213, and 4719 au according to the B3P86, TDHF, and LC-BLYP approximations, respectively, which correspond to 2.5–2.7 times the βHRS of a single Py-CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand. In addition, owing to the tetrahedral structure of b, all methods predict a decrease of the depolarization ratios, by about one unit in comparison with the DR ≈ 5 values of the ligand, associated with its one-dimensional character.

Terminating each bidentate ligand of model b by another tetra-coordinated ZnII center saturated with pyridine and formate moieties to get the neutral model a significantly decreases βHRS but restores more or less the DR of the ligand. In fact, any level of approximation predicts that βHRS(b)/βHRS(a) ≈ 3. We argue that this exaltation of βHRS in b with respect to a comes from the absence of coordination of the terminal ligands and to the global −2 charge of b, whereas a is neutral. The calculations on the bH system substantiate this analysis since its βHRS is as small as 494, 232, and 433 au according to B3P86, TDHF, and LC-BLYP calculations, respectively, i.e., less than 1/10 of those of b. Moreover, the comparison between a and bH demonstrates the important electron-withdrawing role of the Zn2+ cations. The evolution of the amplitude of the nonlinear anisotropy parameter follows inversely that of the depolarization ratios: at any level of approximation, ρ is slightly smaller than one for model a, demonstrating the predominance of the dipolar contribution to β, whereas it is slightly larger than one for model b, corresponding to a slight predominance of the octupolar contribution. Note that the DR of model a is equal to the typical value of one-dimensional NLO-phores (like the ligand), though model a is not one-dimensional. In fact, a looks in first approximation like a typical Λ-shape molecule with two (three for SHG) dominant independent tensor components: using the LC-BLYP XC functional, β yyy = 1338 au and β yxx (≈ β xyx = β xxy ) = 1960 au. Nevertheless, owing to the 3D tetrahedral nature of this compound, there are other nonnegligible tensor components: β yzz (≈ β zyz = β zzy ) = 511 au and the 6 β xyz -like components of 224 au (Table ). In contrast, the DR of b drops to 4.0. The reasons are (i) the repulsion between the negative charges on the two top uncoordinated −COO– groups, which leads to a larger angle between the two Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligands in b than in a, (ii) the exaltation of the major tensor components including β xyz , and (iii) subsequent decrease of the relative amplitude of β yyy with respect to β yxx and β yzz . The DR of bH is slightly smaller than b, confirming the significant influence of the negative charge in model b on β. Comparing the βHRS and DR of a with those of the Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand shows that, though their DR values are almost the same, the βHRS of model a is in fact even smaller than that of a single Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand. These results indicate that the tetracoordinated ZnII centers saturated with pyridine and formate moieties at the ligand terminations have a significant influence on the donor/acceptor (D/A) character of the different moieties and therefore on the β response of the tetrahedral units.

The understanding of the structure/NLO property relationships in MOF and the design of MOF with dedicated NLO responses are, however, still in its infancy, and many aspects remain to be investigated. For instance, the nature of the cation is expected to modify the NLO response. As a preliminary step toward such investigation, we have carried out a calculation of the first hyperpolarizability of the tetrahedral unit of the bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato}-cadmium(II) MOF, the analogue of the title compound where the Zn atoms are replaced by Cd atoms. This has been performed with the LC-BLYP XC functional and the LANL2DZ/6-31G* basis set on the X-ray diffraction geometry. The βHRS response attains 2159 au with a DR of 4.44, both of which are smaller than that in bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato}-zinc(II) MOF (2185 au and 5.11, respectively). The ratio of the βHRS responses, βHRS(Cd)/βHRS(Zn) = 0.99 is similar to the ratios between the SHG responses of the corresponding MOF structures, 345/400 = 0.86, where the SHG activity is given as multiples of the α-quartz value. After geometry optimization, βHRS of the Cd(II) MOF reduces to 1449 au, and the corresponding βHRS(Cd)/βHRS(Zn) ratio to 0.92, in better agreement with the experimental value on the crystal structures.

Sketch of the tetrahedral unit with (model a) and without (model b) the terminal capping ZnII centers. The names of the subunits are also shown (T = top; B = bottom; L = left; R = right).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Sketch of the tetrahedral unit with (model a) and without (model b) the terminal capping ZnII centers. The names of the subunits are also shown (T = top; B = bottom; L = left; R = right).

cln_elements.content: Sketch of the one-dimensional clusters evidencing the direction of the (excitation-induced) charge transfer. Black (gray, light gray) balls are Zn atoms; the lines between balls correspond to the Py–CHCH–Ph–COO– ligand; red arrows show the direction of the (excitation-induced) charge transfer (from −Py to −COO–; the electron transfer goes in the opposite direction); green lines connect the three central Zn atoms; blue arrows show the direction of the dipole moment of the whole cluster; a, c, and d are angles between the ligands along the main charge transfer direction; b is the angle between the dipole moment direction and the direction connecting the three central Zn atoms (plane formed by the 3 central Zn atoms) in 3 L, 3W, and 3yW (3Z) clusters.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Sketch of the one-dimensional clusters evidencing the direction of the (excitation-induced) charge transfer. Black (gray, light gray) balls are Zn atoms; the lines between balls correspond to the Py-CHCH-Ph-COO- ligand; red arrows show the direction of the (excitation-induced) charge transfer (from -Py to -COO-; the electron transfer goes in the opposite direction); green lines connect the three central Zn atoms; blue arrows show the direction of the dipole moment of the whole cluster; a, c, and d are angles between the ligands along the main charge transfer direction; b is the angle between the dipole moment direction and the direction connecting the three central Zn atoms (plane formed by the 3 central Zn atoms) in 3 L, 3W, and 3yW (3Z) clusters.

cln_elements.content: Packing ratios R units (left) and R Zn (right) determined at the TDHF (squares), LC-BLYP (circles), and B3P86 (triangles) levels of approximation for linear (black), W-type (red), Z-type (blue), and yW-type (green) clusters.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Packing ratios R units (left) and R Zn (right) determined at the TDHF (squares), LC-BLYP (circles), and B3P86 (triangles) levels of approximation for linear (black), W-type (red), Z-type (blue), and yW-type (green) clusters.
